title: 107_hr2313
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crane Tithe Tax Act of 2001" and repeals the taxation of corporations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is repealed, including provisions related to corporate income tax, alternative minimum tax for corporations, unrelated business income tax, accumulated earnings tax, personal holding company tax, alternative tax for certain mutual savings banks, tax on life insurance companies, tax on certain mutual insurance companies, tax on certain other insurance companies, and tax on regulated investment companies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is repealed, including provisions related to various taxes imposed on different types of companies such as life insurance companies, mutual insurance companies, other insurance companies, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, and income of foreign corporations connected with United States business. SEC. 3. 10 PERCENT INCOME TAX RATE FOR INDIVIDUALS. Section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to impose a 10 percent income tax rate for individuals. A 10 percent income tax rate is imposed on individuals based on the excess of earned income over the exemption amount, which is $10,000 adjusted for the cost of living. The tax code includes a cost-of-living adjustment based on the Consumer Price Index for urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. If the increase is not a multiple of $10, it is rounded accordingly. The term 'CPI' refers to the Consumer Price Index for all-urban consumers published by the Department of Labor. Any increase not a multiple of $10 is rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. 'Earned income' includes wages, salaries, and net earnings from self-employment. The term 'earned income' generally includes wages, salaries, net earnings from self-employment, and certain dividends. However, it does not include pension or annuity payments, or tips. The term 'earned income' excludes pension, annuity, and discretionary tips, but includes fringe benefits at employer cost. SEC. 4 grants amnesty for all prior tax liability before January 1, 2000, with exceptions for amounts paid before the enactment of the Act and taxes related to illegal activities. SEC. 5 repeals special deductions, credits, and income exclusions for individuals. SEC. 5 repeals special deductions, credits, and income exclusions for individuals. SEC. 6 repeals estate and gift taxes. SEC. 7 specifies effective dates. SEC. 7 of the Act specifies that the amendments will apply to taxable years starting after the enactment date, with the repeal of estate and gift taxes applying to estates of decedents dying after the enactment date. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit any necessary technical changes to the Internal Revenue Code within 90 days of the enactment.
